channel.title: Statistics on Felix Thoemmes
channel.description: Recent content in Statistics on Felix Thoemmes

item.title: Rounding in the age of statcheck
item.description: I recently chatted with a colleague whose work was flagged on PubPeer by the statcheck bot that has been scraping the web last year or so. Her reaction - which I believe is pretty typical - was mild annoyance. To her (and I believe many others) it felt a bit pedantic to be flagged what was essentially a rounding error. She feared that such a flag may create a false impression that the work is a “false positive”, and that people jump to conclusions when they see a statcheck error.

item.title: Keeping exploratory and confirmatory analyses strictly separate
item.description: Recently Wang et al. published a paper in the Journal of Experimental Psychology on pre-registered analyses and the use of covariates in un-registered, exploratory, post-hoc analyses, specifically in the context of randomized experiments 1. I am in 100% agreement with the vast majority of what the authors have to say, and also with the general sentiment of the paper, which I summarize as follows: 1.) Pre-register your analyses and report the results of your pre-registration fully
